channel.title: Thingiverse - Newest Things
channel.description: The newest and coolest things from Thingiverse.com

item.title: Shelf Queen Axles for Crawler
item.description:
Hi guys,

If you have a sweet sweet crawler body shell that you hardly ever run and you're like me, it spends a lot of time sitting on the shelf, alone and forlorn. Why not build a cheap chassis to put it on? These axle housings are dirt cheap if you have a 3D printer. They probably don't make any sense if you don't because you can just buy a set of cheap axles. All you need to make these work really well is a set of cheap drive shafts and some screws.

Dirt cheap drive shafts (the fronts are notoriously weak): https://www.injora.com/products/metal-axle-dogbone-shaft-gear-for-injora-90046-axle-replacement-parts?variant=39449036095536

Still cheap but much better fronts: https://www.injora.com/products/metal-cvd-dogbone-shaft-axle-gear-for-injora-yqcq-02-axle?variant=39727162753072

I would buy the better quality drive shafts: a) if you have an SCX10 and b) you think you might use them in the future for any reason.

You will also need:

4 M2.5x16mm screws to secure the back half of the axle shell
4 M2x8mm screws to secure the pinion carrier

For axles with screw on link mounts:

8 M3x8mm screws to secure link mounts to axle

You can make do with less screws or slightly different lengths, just be sure to check the fit.

I strongly recommend drilling thru holes and pre-tapping screw holes (run a screw into each hole with the parts loose).

Assembly video: https://youtu.be/2pGlL0M1Tlg

Most of the plastic parts from the functional axles I've made are usable as Shelf queen parts but some have bearing cups you will need to account for (use a fake bearing for shelf queen purposes).

For functional axles I would print them at a heat wear stringing begins with near 100% infill. For pure shelf queen, use whatever settings you like.

Parts options (for 2 axles each):

BOM1 (integral link mount on axle) NOT recommended:

2x Axle_L1_Pinion_Side_SQ.stl
2x Axle_L1_Cover_SQ.stl

2x V2_Pinion_Carrier_SQ.stl
2x Axle_Input_Shaft_SQ.stl
2x Fake_Spool_SQ.stl
2x Fake_Rear_Bearing_SQ.stl
2x Rear_Outer_5x11x4_F.stl
1x Left_Caster_Block_SQ.stl
1x mirrored Left_Caster_Block_SQ.stl
1x Injora_Knuckle_SQ.stl
1x mirrored Injora_Knuckle_SQ.stl

4 M2.5x16mm screws to secure the back half of the axle shell
4 M2x8mm screws to secure the pinion carrier

BOM2 (Screw on link mounts):

2x Axle_L2_Pinion_Side_SQ.stl
2x Axle_L2_Cover_SQ.stl
4x Link_Mount_SQ.stl

2x V2_Pinion_Carrier_SQ.stl
2x Axle_Input_Shaft_SQ.stl
2x Fake_Spool_SQ.stl
2x Fake_Rear_Bearing_SQ.stl
2x Rear_Outer_5x11x4_F.stl
1x Left_Caster_Block_SQ.stl
1x mirrored Left_Caster_Block_SQ.stl
1x Injora_Knuckle_SQ.stl
1x mirrored Injora_Knuckle_SQ.stl

4 M2.5x16mm screws to secure the back half of the axle shell
4 M2x8mm screws to secure the pinion carrier
8 M3x8mm screws to secure link mounts to axle

BOM3 (Screw on link mounts AND removeable diff cover):

2x Axle_L2_Pinion_Side_SQ.stl
2x Axle_L2_V2_Cover_SQ.stl
2x Axle_L2_V2_Diff_Cover_SQ.stl
4x Link_Mount_SQ.stl

2x V2_Pinion_Carrier_SQ.stl
2x Axle_Input_Shaft_SQ.stl
2x Fake_Spool_SQ.stl
2x Fake_Rear_Bearing_SQ.stl
2x Rear_Outer_5x11x4_F.stl
1x Left_Caster_Block_SQ.stl
1x mirrored Left_Caster_Block_SQ.stl
1x Injora_Knuckle_SQ.stl
1x mirrored Injora_Knuckle_SQ.stl

4 M2.5x16mm screws to secure the back half of the axle shell
4 M2x8mm screws to secure the pinion carrier
8 M3x8mm screws to secure link mounts to axle

Wrench to drive or drive to wrench?
item.author: WrenchToDrive

item.author: Angelbast

item.title: LED Bottom Lit Display Base
item.description:
This is a LED backlit (or bottom lit) display stand for your 3D prints (I'm using this one for the glow in the dark Eiffel Tower). But It could be used for anything that'll fit on a 135mm x 135mm platform. The base could be scaled up to match your need. It may throw some of the geometry off for the screw holes and the wire pass through hole. As well as the PCB designed for this stand.

For this project, I used a black PLA for the base, and a wood filament for the outer housing. The wood filament was sanded down using 80, and then 220 grit, and then stained with a polyurethane stain from Lowe's. It only needed one coat to get my desired shade.

I used a 3mm sheet of plexiglass that was scuffed on one side to create a "frost" effect. I'm not sure if that's going to be the final piece for production. I may use the same plexiglass but pickup some frost film from Lowe's and see if that diffuses the light any better.

I've attached my gerber file if you'd like to use the PCB as well for the main lighting. I didn't realized it until after the fact, but my Blue and Green terminals are reversed. So from top to bottom its 12V, G, R, B. Just a FYI.

The current PCB supports 64 5050 RGBs. I have a second (way more polished) PCB that I'm waiting on from JLCPBC. That one will have 90 LEDs

As it stands now, the base is super bright.

Pictures will get updated as this project progresses.

Here's some links to everything used in this project.

Wood Stain:
https://www.lowes.com/pd/Minwax-PolyShades-Gloss-Espresso-Oil-Based-Interior-Stain-Actual-Net-Contents-8-fl-oz/999913965

Plexiglass: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B083TR7K9W/ref=cm_sw_r_oth_apip_9bLWMtXBobCTq

5050 RGB Leds:
https://www.amazon.com/Tricolor-Multicolor-Lighting-Electronics-Components/dp/B01CUGABPU/ref=sr_1_1?crid=688LXDLFW2Z9&keywords=5050+leds+components&qid=1643388029&sprefix=5050+leds+components%2Caps%2C42&sr=8-1

200Ω 0603 Resistors:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08QS4DBCX/ref=cm_sw_r_oth_api_glt_i_3E1QX2VT8TVF7ZRK6QRF

M.2 Screw Kit:
https://www.amazon.com/SGTKJSJS-M-2-Screw-NVMe-Mounting/dp/B07Q3DLCJ4

LED Controller:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07RX57HDL/ref=cm_sw_r_awdo_navT_a_HZS3MJVE47FXZYZVT770

item.title: 1930's Streamliner Steam Locomotive
item.description: A Simple model I made of a Streamliner engine from the 1930s. These trains had a unique design for their time that reduced air friction and enabled them to travel faster than other designs. This design was heavily based on the Pennsylvania Railroad No. 3768 engine.

item.author: mr_qusta

item.title: F23 Portable Antenna
item.description:
Summary
The F23 pocket antenna is based on the Diamond F23 design. It’s designed to work as a 3x5/8 wave for a 144-146MHz band, but using the Diamond tuning table, it can be tuned to other frequencies, too (see manufacturer's documentation).

Description
The antenna consists of three coils connected by a radiator wire. Full dimensions and electrical connections can be seen in the attached diagram. The copper wire I used for all the coils has a cross-sectional area of 1.5 mm2, but it can be thinner, though. The radiator I used in the original project was made from a military phone cable used by Eastern Block armies. The capacitor connected to the RF socket with a matching coil was like in an original project (8,2pF 500V) but feel free to use any capacitor with the capacitance between 5 and 10pF rated for 500V.

Assembly
The bottom/matching coil consists of two parts: coil (bottom_coil.stl) and SO239 mount (bottom_mount.stl). After assembling the matching coil, the bottom wire should be passed through the hole in the SO239 mount and bent to be squeezed with the SO239 socket - this way you make a good connection between the SO239 socket and matching coil.

Parts list:

  1. 1x SO239 socket with square mount
  2. 4x M3x10 ball head screw (for SO239 mount)
  3. 5x M3x14 hex head screw (for attaching wires to coils)
  4. 4x M3 cap nut (for SO239 mount)
  5. 12x M3 washer (for making better contact between wire and coils)
  6. 5x M3 wing nut (for attaching wires to coils)
  7. Radiator wire (anything you like ~0.7mm diam)
item.author: infrat

item.author: l_grueni

item.title: Kossel Flying Extruder
item.description:
After printing and testing quite a few flying extruders on here, I got very annoyed with the lack of center over center mounts. Every flying extruder I looked at was always off center creating an S curve on the PTFE tube and pulling the hotend to one side.

I designed and made this to make the extruder to be centered over zero so there was even distribution of force and no tension in the middle. Hope you guys like it.
item.author: Mute916

item.title: Balloonatics Hot Air Balloon Game Pieces
item.description: These are 3D-printed game pieces for The Balloonatics of Gusty Gulch, a board game sold on thegamecrafter.com. These files are provided by the author of said game, for the purpose of having awesome game components. Or maybe you'd just like a hot air balloon model that lays flat? Or some cute clouds? That's fine too.
item.author: Mome_Rath

item.title: Volvo P1800 holder for carburetor oil bottle
item.description:
This is a thingy for your Volvo P1800 that holds your carburetor oil bottle and conveniently clings to your steel bodywork via four standard neodymium magnets. I included two versions - one for the SU-oil bottle with 50 mm diameter and one for the Swedish Förgasar-Olja bottle with 45 mm diameter. The four square magnets are standard 20 x 10 x 3 mm to be found on every major online store and fit snugly into the two openings on the bottom and hold the bottle well in place somewhere convenient. I included some pictures of suggested places near the carbs.

Cheers!
item.author: Photomonkey

item.author: CMYK

item.title: Robo The Fan (1986)
item.description:
Before we completely get into this, THIS IS NOT AN EXACT REPLICA! This is just a close representation of a fan in my bedroom.

My print settings for this and some info.
0.2 Layer Height and 10% infill. Average print scale is 1583.54%. The rest is up to you.
I printed with white PLA and painted with acrylic.
I named my fan "Jerry" and have had it for a long while so that's why the files say Jerry lol.
Arms need supports.
I DID NOT UPLOAD ARMS WITH SUPPORTS BECAUSE MY SUPPORTS ARE NOT VERY GOOD! I recommend you play around with this for a bit until you get a neat creation with the arms.
item.author: SinisterPug

item.title: Boyueda Laotie Janobike Langfeite Footrest Long version
item.description:
Boyueda Laotie Janobike Langfeite Footrest. This is V2 longer version. Great for bigger riders. Print on the side using PetG (reccomended) or PLA.
It helps a lot to keep balance during aggressive ride and is much more convenient than placing foot on standard mudguard support. For handle strength use additional hex screw. M10 100mm with washer and nut will be fine.

My previous shorter version:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4805715
item.author: MakoFPV

item.title: Lambeau Field
item.description:
Remix of a Packer's phone case. This is a model of Lambeau field. The field on a nice stand. No supports required. I printed at 20% infill and 0.12 mm layer height.

Please like and post any makes!
